awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Incorporating Geometric Rules and Cost in Topology  Optimization for Efficient Design of Manufacturable and Economically-Viable Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Topology optimization is a powerful computational aid for exploring novel structural design concepts without requiring a preconceived shape of the structure. The resulting designs are highly optimized for their application, enabling lightweight high-performance structures. However, the designs tend to have an intricate organic-looking structure making them challenging to manufacture reliably and economically. Prior attempts to impose manufacturing constraints during the topology optimization process have had limited success. Furthermore, current methods cannot directly consider manufacturing costs, making it difficult for designers to factor in economic objectives or constraints. This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) award supports fundamental research to formulate the first framework to systematically incorporate geometric design rules and manufacturing cost in topology optimization, and to integrate this framework with educational activities that improve the attitudes of underrepresented minorities towards STEM fields. This research will enable the conceptual design and optimization of lightweight, high-performance, and economically-viable structures with applications across a wide range of engineering industries. The new design capabilities will have the potential to significantly reduce manufacturing and R&D costs and thereby increase the economic competitiveness of American manufacturers. This award will also positively impact underrepresented minorities through an integrated education plan aimed at increasing student self-efficacy and stimulating their participation in STEM. The educational program includes an engaging, virtual-reality based after-school program for middle school students. This program will also engage and impact K-12 teachers and undergraduate and graduate students, and it will be a conduit to communicate research outcomes to the wider public and the research community.

Although topology optimization is a successful technique for structural design, its impact is limited by challenges in incorporating manufacturing constrains and economic considerations into the optimization process. These gaps are rooted in the difficulty to express many manufacturing-driven geometric requirements in terms of the design representations used by existing techniques, the discrete nature of some geometric features, and the fact that manufacturing cost can be a non-smooth function of the design. This CAREER project will make three major intellectual contributions to the computational design of structures, namely the coupling of feature-based design representations with 1) global optimization methods to escape entrapment in undesired local minima in the presence of many geometric design rules; 2) discrete optimization methods to accommodate discrete geometric features; and 3) parametric cost models and non-smooth optimization methods to incorporate cost in the topology optimization problem. The new techniques will be validated against benchmarks and demonstrated on engineering problems in collaboration with industry partners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is to formulate computational methods to incorporate manufacturability considerations in the topology optimization of structural components. Topology optimization methods are computational techniques used to explore lightweight structural designs for superior performance. A key feature of these techniques is that they produce an optimal distribution of material within a given design region without any prior assumption of the shape of the structure. As such, they produce organic designs with exceptional performance, but that can often be costly and impractical for manufacturing, particularly with established and economical fabrication techniques. This project aims to formulate techniques to systematically incorporate geometric design rules and manufacturing cost in topology optimization.

 

At the root of the difficulties to incorporate manufacturing cost and geometric considerations in conventional topology optimization methods is the way in which they represent the structure, namely through a spatial indicator (or density) function that, at any point in the design region, determines whether material must be placed at that point in the optimal design, or through a level set of a function. These geometric representations of the structure provide tremendous degree of freedom and thus render superior designs and, importantly, they can accommodate design changes without having to recreate the discretized model used to predict the structural behavior. However, it is difficult to express quantities such as manufacturing cost or impose geometric constraints to ensure manufacturability in terms of these representations. The overarching approach of this research is to exploit topology optimization techniques whereby the structure is represented as an assembly of geometric primitives, such as bars, plates, or structural shapes. At the heart of this approach is the advancement of geometry projection techniques, in which the high-level parametric descriptions of these primitives are mapped onto a density field, hence as in conventional techniques they circumvent the need to recreate the mesh for analysis.

 

This research produced multiple computational techniques to enable the incorporation of manufacturing cost and geometric requirements in topology optimization. The significant contributions of these techniques include the ability to directly incorporate manufacturing cost as a function in the optimization of structural assemblies, considering the cost of different fabrication steps such as cutting, joining, and finishing structural members, which is challenging to achieve with conventional geometric representations. This project also formulated a tunneling technique that aids the iterative optimization escape convergence to suboptimal designs. Another significant contribution is the formulation of an equivalent section technique that enables the efficient design of frames made of stock structural shapes and that circumvents the need to model all the geometric details of the cross-section of the shape to simulate the behavior of the structure; notably, this technique can design ultralight structures (i.e., with an optimal volume that is less than a percent of the volume of the volume of the design region) using a single computer workstation—a task that is very challenging with conventional methods. This project also produced a method for the topology optimization of assemblies in which the dimensions of the structural members are uncertain, and in which a constraint on the structural reliability is imposed. Another significant contribution is the formulation of a technique to design structures made of curved components, and in which a minimum thickness of the structure is guaranteed to ensure manufacturability and structural integrity.
